cards.title: The week in TV / The Saboteurs, Jordskott and The Legacy
cards.rawTitle: The Saboteurs, Jordskott and The Legacy

item.title: The Saboteurs, Jordskott and The Legacy: TV review
item.trailText: Telly addict Andrew Collins reviews the week's TV, including the new hit Norwegian-Danish-British second world war thriller The Saboteurs
item.standFirst: In his review of the week's TV, telly addict Andrew Collins indulges in a Scandinavian smorgasbord with brand new hit Norwegian-Danish-British second world war thriller The Saboteurs on More4; the latest Nordic noir detective mystery (this time from Sweden), Jordskott, on ITV Encore; the recent epic Danish war drama 1864, on BBC4; the return of family saga The Legacy to Sky Arts; and, for a bit of English-speaking respite, Undercover, a new cop comedy on Dave. Tak!

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for The Saboteurs, Jordskott, The Legacy and more:TV review-video Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: Timelapse video / Stunning images of Earth seen from International Space Station
cards.rawTitle: Stunning images of Earth seen from International Space Station

item.title: Earth seen from International Space Station – timelapse video
item.trailText: Watch a collection of stunning timelapses from the International Space Station, as made by film-maker Dmitry Pisank
item.standFirst: Watch a collection of stunning timelapses from the International Space Station, as made by film-maker Dmitry Pisank, using images and video courtesy of the Earth Science and Remote Sensing Unit, Nasa Johnson Space Centre. Visit The Gateway to Astronaut Photography of Earth for more images and video from the International Space Station

video.source: Courtesy of the Image Science & Analysis Laboratory,  NASA Johnson Space Center, The Gateway to Astronaut Photography of Earth

cards.title: Police video shows Charleston suspect Dylann Roof's arrest
cards.rawTitle: Police video shows Charleston suspect Dylann Roof's arrest

item.title: Police video shows Charleston shooting suspect Dylann Roof's arrest
item.trailText: A police dashboard camera captures the final moments of a 14-hour manhunt for Charleston shooting suspect Dylann Roof
item.standFirst: A police dashboard camera captures the final moments of a 14-hour manhunt for Charleston shooting suspect Dylann Roof. The 21-year-old is charged with the murders of nine black people at Emanuel AME Church in Charleston, South Carolina, last Wednesday. He was captured some 220 miles (350 km) north of the massacre in Shelby, North Carolina, after a tipoff from a member of the public

stillImage.caption: Dylan Roof Photograph: Shelby Police Department Photograph: Shelby Police Department
stillImage.cleanCaption: Dylan Roof Photograph: Shelby Police Department

displayImages.caption: Dylan Roof Photograph: Shelby Police Department Photograph: Shelby Police Department
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dylan Roof Photograph: Shelby Police Department
displayImages.cleanCredit: Shelby Police Department

image.cleanCaption: Dylan Roof Photograph: Shelby Police Department
image.cleanCredit: Shelby Police Department

cards.title: Archive view / Seven decades of Soviet photography

item.title: Seven decades of Soviet photography
item.trailText: From 1927 until after the fall of communism, Russia’s Soviet Photo magazine charted the region’s pioneering visual culture. A new exhibition at Moscow’s Lumiere Centre for Photography celebrates this history
item.standFirst: From 1927 until after the fall of communism, Russia’s Soviet Photo magazine charted the region’s pioneering visual culture. A new exhibition at Moscow’s Lumiere Centre for Photography celebrates this history
item.byline: Yana Iskakova and Ekaterina Zueva for Meduza, part of the New East network

displayImages.caption:
Bathing Homeless, 1927
Born into rural poverty in 1898, Arkady Shaikhet was just 19 years old when the Russian Revolution shook the world. After serving in the war, he honed his technique of ‘artistic reportage’ to document the building of the USSR, and founded the magazine Soviet Photo in 1927 Photograph: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Bathing Homeless, 1927
Born into rural poverty in 1898, Arkady Shaikhet was just 19 years old when the Russian Revolution shook the world. After serving in the war, he honed his technique of ‘artistic reportage’ to document the building of the USSR, and founded the magazine Soviet Photo in 1927
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
The Hands of a Manicurist, 1929
In the years after the founding of Soviet Photo – subtitled Photo-Reporting and Amateur Photography – many artists focused on developing a photographic series, such as this one on hands by Arkady Shaikhet Photograph: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Hands of a Manicurist, 1929
In the years after the founding of Soviet Photo – subtitled Photo-Reporting and Amateur Photography – many artists focused on developing a photographic series, such as this one on hands by Arkady Shaikhet
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Arkady Shaikhet/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Technology Decides Everything, 1930s
Diagonal shots and bold cropping are some of the characteristic techniques used by the infamous left-wing photography collective, October. Their motto was ‘new times demand new forms’
 Photograph: October/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Technology Decides Everything, 1930s
Diagonal shots and bold cropping are some of the characteristic techniques used by the infamous left-wing photography collective, October. Their motto was ‘new times demand new forms’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: October/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Youth, 1937
This photo by Boris Ignatovich shows how later photographers shifted towards socialist realism, which stipulated images had do more than just depict reality – they had to show the communist ideal
Photograph: Boris Ignatovich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Boris Ignatovich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Youth, 1937
This photo by Boris Ignatovich shows how later photographers shifted towards socialist realism, which stipulated images had do more than just depict reality – they had to show the communist ideal
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Boris Ignatovich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Dietary Eggs, 1939
Alexander Khlebnikov founded the Innovator Photography Club and was a pioneer of still life photography. This image of a plate of eggs is one of a number he took throughout the 1930s of household objects – from fabric to pumpkin seeds to milk bottles
 Photograph: Alexander Khlebnikov/MeduzaLumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Alexander Khlebnikov/MeduzaLumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dietary Eggs, 1939
Alexander Khlebnikov founded the Innovator Photography Club and was a pioneer of still life photography. This image of a plate of eggs is one of a number he took throughout the 1930s of household objects – from fabric to pumpkin seeds to milk bottles
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Alexander Khlebnikov/MeduzaLumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
The Enemy, 1944
With the outbreak of world war two, photojournalism was enlisted in defence of Mother Russia. In this photo by Anatoli Egorov, who was wounded in action, corporal Stepan Vasiljevich Ovcharenko shoots at enemy troops with a machine gun Photograph: Anatoli Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Anatoli Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Enemy, 1944
With the outbreak of world war two, photojournalism was enlisted in defence of Mother Russia. In this photo by Anatoli Egorov, who was wounded in action, corporal Stepan Vasiljevich Ovcharenko shoots at enemy troops with a machine gun
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Anatoli Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Meet the Winners, 1945
A master of Soviet photography and colleague of leading painter Alexander Rodchenko and pioneering filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein, George Petrusov captured the elation of the crowd at the end of the second world war. Rodchenko said of Petrusov: ‘He’s like a sponge that absorbs everything about photography’ Photograph: George Petrusov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: George Petrusov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Meet the Winners, 1945
A master of Soviet photography and colleague of leading painter Alexander Rodchenko and pioneering filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein, George Petrusov captured the elation of the crowd at the end of the second world war. Rodchenko said of Petrusov: ‘He’s like a sponge that absorbs everything about photography’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: George Petrusov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Concrete Factory, 1954
After serving in the second world war, Vsevolod Tarasevich went back to photography, working for Sovyetsky Soyuz, Ogonyok and Rabotnitsa magazines, as well as Soviet Photo. Much of his work is concerned with the virtues and achievements of science and technology Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Concrete Factory, 1954
After serving in the second world war, Vsevolod Tarasevich went back to photography, working for Sovyetsky Soyuz, Ogonyok and Rabotnitsa magazines, as well as Soviet Photo. Much of his work is concerned with the virtues and achievements of science and technology
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Perfume No8, 1958
This picture, the eighth in a series on perfume, shows Alexander Khlebnikov’s move into fashion and advertising photography in the 1950s Photograph: Soviet Photo/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Soviet Photo/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Perfume No8, 1958
This picture, the eighth in a series on perfume, shows Alexander Khlebnikov’s move into fashion and advertising photography in the 1950s
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Soviet Photo/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Start, 1959
Taken from an article about the production of a new camera model – the Start – by Vladimir Stepanov Photograph: Vladimir Stepanov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vladimir Stepanov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Start, 1959
Taken from an article about the production of a new camera model – the Start – by Vladimir Stepanov
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vladimir Stepanov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
In the Physics Lab, 1960
Anatoly Khrupov was another photographer of the ‘physicist-lyricists’ behind the achievements of Soviet science. Here, he photographs a technician at work in the lab of Vilnius University in Lithuania Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
In the Physics Lab, 1960
Anatoly Khrupov was another photographer of the ‘physicist-lyricists’ behind the achievements of Soviet science. Here, he photographs a technician at work in the lab of Vilnius University in Lithuania
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
The Twelfth Symphony, 1961
This portrait of the renowned composer Dmitry Shostakovich represents a shift in Soviet poraiture: instead of a posed picture, photographer Vsevolod Tarasevich found out where the composer rested between performances, and shot a candid image in secret Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Twelfth Symphony, 1961
This portrait of the renowned composer Dmitry Shostakovich represents a shift in Soviet poraiture: instead of a posed picture, photographer Vsevolod Tarasevich found out where the composer rested between performances, and shot a candid image in secret
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
The Duel, 1963
The political thaw of the 1960s brought with it a new energy in photography, as this image, from the series ‘Moscow State University’, by Vsevolod Tarasevich shows Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Duel, 1963
The political thaw of the 1960s brought with it a new energy in photography, as this image, from the series ‘Moscow State University’, by Vsevolod Tarasevich shows
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vsevolod Tarasevich/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Khrushchev and Castro have lunch at a kolkhoz in Georgia, 1963.
Over 38 days, Cuba’s Fidel Castro travelled all over the USSR – the only state leader to do so. It was widely publicised in the Soviet press, and this image of the two enjoying lunch was taken by Vasily Egorov Photograph: Vasily Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vasily Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Khrushchev and Castro have lunch at a kolkhoz in Georgia, 1963.
Over 38 days, Cuba’s Fidel Castro travelled all over the USSR – the only state leader to do so. It was widely publicised in the Soviet press, and this image of the two enjoying lunch was taken by Vasily Egorov
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vasily Egorov/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
University gymnastics, Moscow, 1973
Experimenting with form and abstraction, this collage of four different photos taken by Alexander Abaza turns a gymnastics routine into an alphabet of gestures Photograph: Alexander Abaza/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Alexander Abaza/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
University gymnastics, Moscow, 1973
Experimenting with form and abstraction, this collage of four different photos taken by Alexander Abaza turns a gymnastics routine into an alphabet of gestures
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Alexander Abaza/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Tales of the Sea, 1976
Lithuanian photographer Vitaly Butyrin draws on a rich Soviet history with his often surreal photo-montages. This is taken from a series called ‘Tales of the Sea’ Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Tales of the Sea, 1976
Lithuanian photographer Vitaly Butyrin draws on a rich Soviet history with his often surreal photo-montages. This is taken from a series called ‘Tales of the Sea’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Behind the scenes at the Bolshoi Theatre, 1983
Taken from a series which won Vladimir Vytkin his first World Press Photo award nomination, the photograph came during a time when Vytkin was deeply critical of what he said were ‘uneventful’ trends in Soviet photography Photograph: Vladimir Vytkin/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.credit: Vladimir Vytkin/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Behind the scenes at the Bolshoi Theatre, 1983
Taken from a series which won Vladimir Vytkin his first World Press Photo award nomination, the photograph came during a time when Vytkin was deeply critical of what he said were ‘uneventful’ trends in Soviet photography
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Vladimir Vytkin/Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

displayImages.caption:
Army Diary Page, 1989
Born in 1963, the early years of Vadim Gushchin’s career coincided with the economic and political reform years of glasnost and perestroika under Mikhail Gorbachev. His later work veered towards minimalism and still life, but in 1989 he released a series of mixed-media images called Army Diary Pages

A version of this gallery first appeared on Meduza, part of the New East network Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Army Diary Page, 1989
Born in 1963, the early years of Vadim Gushchin’s career coincided with the economic and political reform years of glasnost and perestroika under Mikhail Gorbachev. His later work veered towards minimalism and still life, but in 1989 he released a series of mixed-media images called Army Diary Pages

A version of this gallery first appeared on Meduza, part of the New East network
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Lumiere Brothers Center for Photography

item.title: Royal Ascot: a class act – interactive
item.trailText: The Guardian’s chief sports photographer Tom Jenkins covered Royal Ascot, one of the highlights of the flat racing – and social season
item.standFirst: Guardian sports photographer Tom Jenkins went to cover one of the highlights of the British flat racing – and social season. Records were broken, champagne was quaffed and the crowds had a jolly good day out ...

displayImages.altText: A group of girls in matching outfits are watched over by stewards during Royal Ascot day one at Ascot racecourse on June 16th 2015 in Berkshire (Photo by Tom Jenkins)
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: The fashion wish list / Men's espadrilles

item.title: Men's espadrilles: the wish list
item.trailText: This summer invest in a pair of espadrilles and treat your feet to a flexible jute sole
item.standFirst: This summer invest in a pair of espadrilles and treat your feet to a flexible jute sole. The perfect footwear to look effortless in and finish your high summer look. Choose from a crafted woven design, suede or simple canvas in an array of colours, and you’ll infuse a little coolness into those hot summer days

cards.title: Take a deep breath ... / Inside Sweden's longest underwater cave

item.title: Inside Sweden's longest underwater cave
item.trailText: Divers from Sweden, Finland and Norway explore Sweden's longest underwater cave
item.standFirst: Divers from Sweden, Finland and Norway explore Sweden's longest underwater cave. Explorers first need to break the ice to reach the entrance to Dolinsjö cave in the county of Jämtland. Divers use headlamps to light their path and need to stop for coffee breaks to rest and regain warmth in air-filled sections of the cave. So far the expedition has reached 1.7km into the cave, but it is not known how far it stretches
